It may be just a matter of time before the Shakopee facility no longer exists.

review_title: Awesome Place to Work, Learn, Grow
pros:
The people and environment at Seagate are amazing.  
-Positive Environment
-Reasonable demands
-Spirit of growth, learning and innovation
-Realistic expectations of work hours
-Awesome management
-Great Learning opportunities
cons:
Seagate is an old manufacturing company, it is still a bit slow to adapt.

It's tough to get contracts with vendors executed in a timely manner, making it a bit challenging to meet goals.  

Leadership can be a bit harsh and occasionally unrealistic in their demands for speed to market for certain programs.

Every campus has different perks and benefits, so it's hard to speak for the company as a whole, but the Cupertino campus is limited as far as recreational (gym, cafeteria) options, and the locker room is seriously tiny and lacking in privacy.

review_title: Interesting work, good colleagues, family friendly
pros: Skill development is encouraged. Pretty good mobility within the company if you want to try a new areas. Company is expanding beyond just hard drives. Flexible hours make it easy to accommodate family stuff. Wide range of work available. Some people like to be narrow specialist and others are broad generalists, both kinds of engineers are valued.  Social culture, lots of leagues and civic opportunities. New exciting projects.
cons: Typical big company problems. Occasionally you run into someone who isn't getting the job done. Eventually it gets sorted out, but it can take a while for the hierarchy of management to zero in on the problem. New development is fun, but there is also a fair amount of legacy stuff that is expected to not be touched.

review_title:
Very good and technically challenging work.
Interesting design projects for mechanical graduates too.
pros:
1) Very lenient work timings.
2) friendly senior staff and colleagues 
3) As the entire business is being shifted to India..lots of research projects @ BNGL seagate
4) For mech guys, interesting designing work in the field of shock and vibrations setups, thermal testrigs etc. Hardware design for many MNC company products etc
5) Though not more, descent refreshing activities, sports and competitions once in a while.
6) good pay for a beginner.
cons:
1) BNGL seagate yet to develop a lot. Though many projects are being researched on, only few have made it to market.
Takes some time..to justify the business shift to India. 
2) managerial routine or processes are not yet defined well. Under constant reformation cause of the all new developing team. Again..takes time.

review_title: High Risk Profile. Think before joining
pros:
* Good Transport Services
* Good HR Services/Policies
* Good Office Setups
* Good IT Infrastructure
* Good Salary
* Focus on branding
cons:
* Too Frequent layoffs. Anyone (even class performer) can be impacted
* Unsure/unclear about long-term strategy. Mostly short-term trial goals leading to losses.
* Poor response to market requirement. Poor decision making 
* Frequent acquisitions, mostly going wrong, adding to overhead
* Unable to encash the true potential. Recovery using layoffs.
* In addition to layoffs, they have been closing down centers frequently.

review_title: Excellent place to work for an engineer
pros:
Seagate Technology provides as many challenges as you want.  If you are interested in technical work or project management, there are plenty of opportunities.  
They encourage physical fitness and group activities. Excellent culture overall. Everyone treats each other with respect and there are some of the smartest people I have worked with here. 
The true strength of the workforce is in the contribution of ground level employees.
cons:
Executive management tends to be entrenched and out of touch, which can be frustrating to the workforce.  
Very little opportunity for functional management.  Most managers have been there a long time with no plans to move.  This can lead to a restriction in getting fresh thinking into management.

review_title: Join this company if you want to spoil your career
pros: Life balance is good. You have option to purchase a stock, WFH is available. Culture is good
cons: As this company is working more in hardware  than software, it absolutely failed to create the software like cloud solutions etc. Once the work is started I came to know that in many projects there is very small work that can be done by 3 software engineers but management assigned 10 software engineers for such a small work.  After joining this company, in 3 months they put many people in other project where the technologies are 0% matched with professional experience. The reason is that they want  people to leave this company,  this is communicated indirectly. There is no future roadmap. They blindly hired many people.  After 6 months, this project has been sold out to some other company which is US based and more than 30 people came on bench in just 6 months.

pros: I enjoyed my time at Seagate in EMEA, its the smaller region for the company so can feel like a poor relation at times.  However, everyone I met and worked with was professional and open to working together.  Its a Company I would happily work for again.
cons:
Financial Results are not where they could be, seems like a lot of cuts are being made and are they for the best.  A new CEO from outside the Company would have a been a wiser choice than internal promotion - more of the same it seems.

EMEA Region is small and often overpowered by US and APAC due to relative populations.

review_title: Senior leadership and company sucess hindered by sub-par first level management
job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in Longmont, CO
pros: Big, generally stable company that is making money right now. Seem to be paying very close attention to market pressures, changing storage environments, and competitors. Great communication from the top expression company vision, short and long term goals and expectations. Local HR and EH&S work hard to create a pleasent work environment and maintain a first class facility.
cons: Big, slow moving company disconnected with the individual contributor. First level managers ill equiped and sometimes unwilling to actually manage and motivate contributors. Reorignations locallized and do not seem to effect real change. Top level communications seems to be stifled by local frst level management that don't really buy into corporate message.

pros: Seagate has a very relaxed and laid back atmosphere.  Many of their employees have been there for 10 years or more which shows that they are good to their employees.  I worked at the OKC location and they paid very well for an Oklahoma salary(the cost of living is low here and so are most salaries).
cons: When I was leaving, their stock dropped somewhat and people were starting to worry about their jobs.  I have since heard that two of the employees I had worked with were laid off.  They were both new grads who had only been there a couple months.

review_title: Was once a great employer in OKC
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Good compensation, time off and sick days. Was at one time a great place to work.
cons: Corporate wants to see the Oklahoma City location wiped off the site map. Does not care about the employees or how our customers are treated. Inconsistent Corporate Culture and terrible communication from the top. Demands loyalty and hard work from employees but treats employees as dispensable liabilities when hard times come. Was once a great place to be but has decayed into nothing.

pros: I was lucky enough to have a very good manager who made sure I had challenging projects, access to necessary resources, and who made sure I was introduced to those around the company that might help me farther down the line. Work-Life balance was also very good...until the off-shoring model, that is.
cons: Recent company hiring changes have made it impossible to ever see a raise without changing jobs. Also, 'hiring from within' is no longer the custom. The company's openly stated hiring strategy is to hire the most inexperienced person (read: youngest) who might be able to handle the job as a way to keep salary costs down. In addition, international teams require late nights for US workers.

pros: Its a job in an area short of employment.  Wish I had more to say but there is nothing.
cons:
Bad wages (operator) , pathetic bonuses. Forced to use holidays or unpaid for factory closures. Vindictive bullying management backed by HR . Religious disparity used in  promotion , 90% of promotions go to the minority group (less than 5% of operators). Operators with illness harassed into resigning . Completely different set of rules for operators regarding pay rises , bonuses , illness and practically everything in between. 
Good honest hardworking people do not get promoted , the weasels and informants do. Management turns a blind eye to the deserving and embraces those who kiss their feet.

job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Had a great team of co-workers that supported each other.
Good benefits.
In IT so I am able to tele-commute.
Global teams.
My manager looks at for our team.
cons:
Most employees have bookmarked web sites to track layoff rumors to keep upto date on pending cuts.
TOO MANY good people have been laid off this year.  The ones left are over worked.
No raise in 5 years.
Cuts made from senior management level with no input from managers.  This left huge gaps to be filled by the people left behind.
Moving all IT support to APAC teams.

pros: Getting to work on leading edge technology and they don't nickle and dime you on the tools you need to do your job. Management in the building is generally sensible.
cons: Pay is below market, and no raises while they continue to increase dividends and share buybacks. Near quarterly layoffs for the last 2 years create a lot of fear and turmoil. Many engineering groups are understaffed and struggle to make goals. Since they continue to "find efficiencies" career growth opportunity is essentially 0. Health insurance is not particularly great with now mandatory high deductible health plan.

review_title: Lots of potential but slow to change
pros:
Lots of super smart people trying to do the right thing.
Good technology and product development process.
Good benefits with emphasis on health and wellness.
cons:
Lots of bureaucracy, inefficient systems, and reliance on manual processes.  
Upper management seems pretty disconnected from the workforce.  
Bullying behavior is tolerated.

review_title: Perpetual layoffs for the workers while bonuses for executive management
pros: Nice building to work in.  Nice health and fitness center and cafeteria.  Co-workers are great.
cons: In my opinion, focus is on cost cutting to make numbers.  Continuous layoffs, outsourcing, downsizing so Wall Street can make a nickel and management gets their bonuses. Watch out if you have grey hair or you could be the next to go.  Yeah I know they don't discriminate against older people, yeah, yeah, yeah.  HR is completely aligned with management so don't expect anything from them.

pros: You will get a chance to work with few high notch talented people. Lot of opportunities to learn and grow. Senior management are concerned about your learning curve.
cons: You can't predict your career. You may lose your job even after performing well. Sometimes your reporting manager may not allow you to go out of box. No onsite opportunity to learn better about ongoing or sustainable products. No work life balance.

pros: Very open work environment in the flash (SSD) group. Also there is no difference of work between what is done in the US vs in BLR. In fact all the new work lands in BLR. The upper management is very pro bangalore and one can see very big chunks or projects being transferred to BLR. The local management is also very helpful and sensitive. Very good work life + technical growth environment.
cons: As for any big company, there are some overheads in this company too. But the flash division i am in has the culture of coming from a small company, so kind of we are hidden from the seagate culture.

pros: Co-workers are great as we are all in the same boat of doing more with less.  Us vs. them mentality leads to tighter work units, but comes at a cost because distrust of company is high.
cons: Sr. Management ever changing and seems to not know what direction they want to lead the company.  Strategies sway quarter to quarter, no real feel that they know what's going on.  Business is in decline, pay is in decline, bonus non-existent, no reason for many to stay.  Layoffs looming.

review_title: Don't go for Object Store group.
pros:
# Good learning if you work on VLSI stuff. 
# Very knowledgable and experienced people if you are in VLSI group.
# Flexible timings
cons:
# Doesn't provide much facilities for employees
# Salary is not good compared to other product based companies like Nvidia, AMD, Intel
# If you are working on their new Object Store product, Seagate is like a startup without startup salary. Extremely heavy workload with few people to work on.
# Seagate doesn't spend much on employees so don't expect merchandise, parties, free food and bonuses.
# If you are working on their new Object Store product there is no work life balance for you.

review_title: Good culture but tough place to work.
job_title: Senior Director in Scotts Valley, CA
pros: A good place to gain experience. A no nonsense culture -- there is the usual big company bureaucracy but it is kept to a minimum where possible. Throughout all levels of management there is a healthy respect for people and their lives.
cons: The disk drive industry is very tough and commodity based. Stock will never be valued by the market. In tough times, the company will not hesitate to get rid of you. For the past 5 years there has been very little opportunity for career growth and promotions.

review_title: Was great, but trending quickly downward
pros:
Smart, amazing co-workers
Data based decisions
Professional business processes, strong 6 sigma spirit of data and improvement
High pay and decent (though diminishing) benefits
cons:
Hard Disk Drive portion of the business is changing dramatically, so a layoffs every 6-9 months.  Not a lot of upward or even lateral mobility in a contracting company.
Environment has moved from excellence, risk taking and strong meritocracy to a lot of politics, cronyism, and conservatism - the other reviews about the good ol' boys network are sadly true now, too.

pros: Great people. The building is nice. Nice walking path. The grounds are well maintained. The company gives profit share bonuses. The only company left that does that anymore.
cons: The rating system for job performance is outdated and ridiculous.  Everyone gets a 3 out of 5 no matter your contributions. Which directly affects the bonuses. Management is unrealistic as far as expectations from the employees. They are outsourcing IT so the employees will get no support for their computer needs. Which will greatly impeded the work being done there.

job_title: Senior Program Manager in Longmont, CO
pros: Many talented, hard working people.  Pay, benefits and training are first-rate!  There is an introductory course in disc drive technology, and many in-depth courses beyond that that are worthwhile and most are provided on-site.
cons: The majority of folks are committed to the team's success - some of management is not.  Lay-off's happen to all businesses during down-times.  You need to be flexible and able to deal with ambiguity, as the requirements for a product can change on a daily basis.

review_title: An OK place to work, but time for me to move on
job_title: Software Engineer II in Shakopee, MN
pros: Willing to accommodate your schedule with a good work-life balance, until crunch time hits that is.  Management lets you do your work without micromanaging you.  Fun leagues and activities with co-workers.
cons: Dismal outlook in the SSD department.  Management is unable to draft realistic project schedules that we can adhere to.

review_title: Decent place to work but could do without the stress
pros: One of the best reasons to work for Seagate is that it is a fairly big company with plenty of work to do.  The colleagues I work with a very driven and intelligent and I enjoy working alongside them.  There is a lllllottt of work and so the sluggish economy does not have any effect on the morale of the people because there is no fear about no work = layoffs.
cons: The disc drive business is cut-throat, and most of the time the leads are stressed out, which reflects on their behavior towards their coworkers.

job_title: Lead Product Assurance Engineer in Shakopee, MN
pros:
Is a World wide company with vast resources and many different opportunities relating to all things data storage. They are currently are positioning themselves to continue to be an industry leader in a changing storage media environment.
The benefits are fairly industry standard, which is to say they are good. There are always opportunities for internal career movement and they do a good job of allowing for a good work life balance.
cons: It is a very large company and can make one feel small especially when decisions come down from on high that seem arbitrary. Recently they have been downsizing and expecting more from fewer employees creating opportunities for challenge but also high levels of pressure/stress.

pros: Work/Life Balance: being part of a large company, its easier to schedule your work if you have a need to take time off to attend to your life!. Excellent Benefits Package: salaries are generally good, although the astronomically high cost of bay area housing means you are still stretched, when it comes to finances.
cons: Lack of clear communication from senior management: now that the CEO and COO are changed, it can get better. There have been issues with Respect for non-professional staff, specially when it came to grant them stock options. Also, there is a tendency to have surprises up the senior management's sleeves, as to who gets to stay and who gets to leave!

pros: Seagate was the best company I ever worked for; it had great benefits and flexibility.  I was given opportunities to excel beyond the scope of my job.  I would work for Seagate again if given the opportunity.
cons: When I tried to change positions at Seagate, I was given next to no training.   Even an HR person said that Seagate expects you to stay in the position you are hired for and not move.  Also, there was some favoritism in the department that affected many of us.

review_title: 30+ years in manufacturing, corporate culture severely declining
pros: Good benefits, nice facilities overall, industry leader (1st and 2nd place in various areas)
cons: Location from where most employees lived (Santa Cruz County); lack of raises; lack of bonuses; when someone leaves the company or is let go, others will have to take over the job responsibilities without the position being back-filled; fear of retaliation of issues that might get brought up; lack of management response to issues needing addressing (turning a blind eye/good ol' boys club); if you want a promotion, you have to leave the company; no respect or concern for the humanity working at the company.

review_title: dead-end job with no career advancement or growth
pros: Flexible work schedule ( depends on the manager)
cons:
Political culture with constantly changing management. Company strategy is changing all the time. Pay is lower compared to other companies in the valley.Even when the company was doing well, the bonus was reduced for everyone. 
The manager basically decides your future. There is no feedback to manager at all.If you have a bad manager, then basically your future is screwed. Old company culture with old coworkers who are very satisfied with the old way of doing things. Company is not looking for the best people to hire but hires a lot of people with "special relationships".

pros: If you enjoy having teleconferences with staff in India starting at 6am, then again at 9pm nearly every day, and you like being a direct report to management in India, then this company is for you.
cons: This place is "all in" on moving to India, so unless you're in India (or unless you're at the level of management that's sending all of the jobs there) you have no future at STX. The best that you can hope for is a slow, lingering decline into the maw of job termination.

pros: Great people, decent work-life balance.   Pay is very competitive.   HDD's are a very mature technology but that also means each improvement requires very challenging engineering problems to be solved.  Not a military/government/medical product so there are not regulation hurdles that prevent some the newest and most exotic tech.
cons:
Company spends a lot of time convincing employees of a stable business which in itself is troubling; especially given the amount of recent layoffs and site closures. 
 No clear long term path to address markets outside of spinning disk.   There are some 'big company' business process headaches.

job_title: Order Management in Scotts Valley, CA
pros: it is a cutting edge company that is in a great position to grow.  I was working there through a temp agency though so I didn't feel the same level of pride i would have as a regular employee.  They have great technology and have partnerships with some amazing companies, and they are sure to grow as disk storage becomes a larger and larger field in the near future.  Everyone I worked with was great as well, and my manager was amazing. If I had more of a career path that I could have worked with there I would have loved to stay.
cons: the building is somewhat dated and the cafeteria is too expensive.

review_title: Technology company that needs to come back from years of poor management.
job_title: Senior Finance Analyst in Longmont, CO
pros: Exciting technology, lots of intelligent people, reasonable chances for promotions with hard work.  Decent salary and lots of autonomy.  Great technology to work with and a comfortable business environment.  Great health benefits.
cons: Pace of technological change can lead to burn out.  Questionable management practices.  Endless layers of management.  Everything is priority number one, and therefore nothing is done really well.  Management sets unreasonable goals that are almost never achieved - this results in a regular feeling of failure.  Morale is very low.

job_title: Process Engineer II in Farmington, MN
pros:
Great work life balance
Highly diverse
Training for career advancement is provided internally
Very challenging work
cons:
There have been no promotions or pay increases in the last three years.
Layoff are occurring every 2-3 years like clockwork.
The people who are let go are the ones doing the work while the folks that are just here to collect a paycheck get to stay.
If you are good at your job, you are rewarded by getting to do other people's jobs too.

review_title: Good company for work Life Balance
pros: Its good company for people who want very good work life balance in their life , You have good package already and you are married with Kids, so come here . You can give good time to your family with this company.
cons: For fresher who want to learn more , there could be very slow learning curve here. Financial restriction, Promotions are not done  even though you perform good ,If you ask about then only you will get it . Annual salary hikes are also cancelled if quarter reports are not good . HR n many other departments work like Indian Government officers(Slow & with bad management ethics)

review_title: RIF, RIF, RIF the folks over 40
pros: Good compensation and benefits, some amazing people to work with, some horrible ones as well. They will give you every tool you need to succeed and excel in your position...
cons: Two rounds (or more) of RIFs every year. The entire RIF list contains nothing but folks over 40. They are screaming for an age discrimination law suit like the one they paid out in 2011... Seems they never learn

job_title: Process Engineering Intern in Derry, Northern Ireland
pros: This was a really relaxed atmosphere to work in with friendly staff. The work was challenging but rewarding. As an intern I was made to feel like part of the company and not just "the intern". My work consisted of a few different projects that actually contributed to the company.
cons: Overall I didn't find many downsides. HR wasn't great though. I later applied for a graduate role and despite reaching the interview stage, I didn't hear back from HR.

job_title: Supply Chain Analyst in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Work with many different people across the globe.

The people are encouraging and always willing to offer assistance need be. 


 You are definitely able to gain supply chain and demand forecasting experience.  Also gain valuable inventory control experience.
cons:
Work can be monotonous, can turn into a weekly grind. 

There is rarely anything new or exciting offered. 

Company culture and team bonding is not something that Seagate Technology takes too seriously. 

Team building exercises are very few far from between.

review_title: Not the best place for young engineers
pros:
- Fair starting compensation 
- Flexible hours 
- Emphasize physical fitness and well-being 
- One of two worldwide HDD suppliers
cons:

- Poor company culture: thick office politics, problem solving frequently consists of blaming other groups and teammates instead of taking responsibility and working together
- Frequent layoffs

review_title: Good people but a bit bad work condition
job_title: Full Stack Developer in Nakhon Ratchasima
pros:
- Cost of living was very low. They provide internal canteen with super low price dishes. 
- Very convenient to commute to work, I lived in an apartment next to the company and walk to work. 
- Manage training session and seminar to improve staffs. 
- Good team members.
cons: I supported production users to help them improve their process by providing applications. As Seagate is an HDD manufacturing, so top management value production and treat IT as just a supporting team. They do not care how do you implement those apps, they just want it rapidly. Sometimes we did not do enough testing because of the time limit.

review_title: Seagate RHO uses the latest design and process technologies to develop next-generation magnetic hard drive products.
job_title: Senior Development Engineer in Bloomington, MN
pros: Many smart people work together on challenging projects. Most people have worked for Seagate at least a decade, but there is room for upward movement as people transfer internally or retire. The leaders give employees room to experiment and have a good work-life balance.
cons: Employee reorganizations happen often, are sudden, and can be accompanied by layoffs. The reorgs are top-down with little input from the bulk of employees. Some upper level managers seem ignorant to rising technological disruptions.

pros: Some of the employees are great to work with and good benefits.
cons: Poor communications across the board, silos, management heavy  and management does not listen or care to listen.  Outsourcing to companies whose staff are not properly trained causing more rework for the employees resulting in a higher expense to the company.  With the higher costs not being tracked nor are those expenses shown in the ROI or project totals.

job_title: Content Strategist in San Jose, CA
pros: Peers were great; at least most of them.  Atmosphere was collaborative.  Made some good friends. Work was rewarding.
cons:
Management was unorganized and whole departments were overlooked for their contributions.  Some groups were laid off in a short amount of time.  Many old timers were just vesting in place and difficult to work with. 

Had to pay back an entire hiring bonus a few months from the end of the two year stipulation.  Bonuses were smallest I have seen in the valley.  They were usually accompanied by an apology  for being so small.

pros:
Great people here working under conditions that are pretty demotivating, and after numerous rounds of layoffs, and no salary increases for several quarters.

Smart people that treat the job as the boss and that are willing to help you out and go to any length during onboarding. Some very good teammates and coworkers. 

Bonuses can be nice, the 401k match is pretty good, and the benefits aren't terrible.  For some people it seems possible to literally do almost nothing and keep your job. 

Vacation is "unlimited" provided it doesn't affect business.

Bottom line: it's good experience. You'll have plenty of situations that will give you great questions to ask during your next interview.
cons:
Aging management stuck in old ways for fear of producing mistakes unseen for months downstream. People overqualified for their positions prone to take actions solely for the sake of appearing to be doing something, even if it has no impact or makes the problem worse. 

Performance is somewhat diminished in relevance since there salary increases are rare and people are almost never terminated for incompetence or idle work ethic.  

Nearly all of my colleagues consider the company to be somewhat of a joke. There is no real loyalty or dedication to the job, just an attempt to stay beneath suspicion and do what one is told to minimize grief. 

Extremely male company.  Expect locker room talk and the social mores of 60 year old white men.

You'll often have director-level staff micromanaging two levels beneath them, worrying about nickel and dime expenses. Enjoy a 20 person meeting focusing in on singular production errors where an email would do. Middle managers are the embodiment of the Dilbert Principle.  Why hire people and make them into marionettes? Set their talents loose. 

If you have to deal with technicians or trade staff expect a TON of grief to get anything done. Don't expect repeat errors that trash your KPIs to get fixed or addressed. There are many untrainable people in their 2nd or 3rd decade. Some of the staff seem to exist only to make work for the competent staff. Six Sigma is totally undone by these gear-wrenches.

Thinned workforce means responsibilities are very broad, expect to be asked to do clerical and other boring checklist-level work.

review_title: Nice relaxed atmosphere and the people are very nice.
pros:
Casual Day every day (shorts, jeans etc.)
Great work life balance
Work from home policy very flexible
cons:
Too many redundant tools used due to lack of direction from executive management.
Incompetent management throughout the organization. 
No career growth.
Not enough training for worker-bees, yet execs take boon-doogles all the time.
Raises not competitive.

review_title: Seagate Technology Rating from longtime senior staff engr
job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in Fremont, CA
pros: Flexible hours, safe work environment, reasonable commute, good work-life balance, nice people, reasonable pay, interesting projects, tuition assistance, continuous learning and improvement, onsight toastmasters club
cons: not much opportunity for career growth, hdd industry is on the decline, can get stuck doing same job for many years, recently 1 week of vacation was taken away from longterm employees, stock is on the decline, bonuses are shrinking, last focal review had across the board pay freeze.

job_title: Senior Engineering Director in Bloomington, MN
pros: Company invests heavily in research and development and manufacturing capabilities, strives to pursue technology and product leadership and promote technical innovations. It provided diversified, open and supportive environment for self-motivated engineers to contribute and grow. Team members are encouraged to take initiatives to come up creative ideas, and relatively easier for them to get resources to execute their ideas.
cons: The hard drive technology may have passed its peak period. The technical expertise gained in some areas may be getting too narrow which could limit future career development.

review_title: Seagate  strong brain power poor management
pros: Seagate is the largest manufacturer of hard discs. If you would like to be involved in developing cutting edge technology seagate is a good place to work for. One of the few companies where there is still significant investment in Research and Development areas. Best talent pool.
cons: Highly stressful and competitive environment. Heavily layered. Too many management levels.  No work life balance. No coordination between different organizations. Redundency at all levels.  Promotion of self agendas  rather than a common vision.

review_title: Good place to work, but could improve
pros: The compensation is good, and the company is flexible about your time off and working hours.  The U.S. sites are outgrowing the 8-5 working hours culture and recognizing that business in a company that circles the globe happens 24 hours a day.
cons: Still uses a stacked ranking system and there is little visibility to comparisons between departments.  This forces the same distribution of rankings down to a small department level.  If you hire well and build a talented department this can be very demotivating.

pros: Good benefits. Especially if you have been there for over 5 years (good vacation, severance package). Healthcare.
cons:
Everyone in mgmt has been at the Company (or industry) for over 20 years and has large paychecks. They can't leave b/c it's impossible to get a the same paycheck elsewhere. Lot's of complacency. Cubicles and gray walls. Morale is low. No real culture, it's just a job. People are viewed as a commodity just the hard drives we sell. 

No bonuses or focals.

pros: Employess are very friendly, helpful to work with and given the size of the company there is usually someone available to help with issues/questions. Bonus are nice when the numbers are met.
cons: Huge amounts of labor and money were thrown at the EVault merger and it was poorly managed at the top levels. Just as most systems and teams were merged, Seagate undid the merger and pushed Evault back out on its own, but as a fraction of what it was.

pros: Lots of good people, but they are leaving or left.
cons: Ibworked for Seagate for 17 years and am very thankful for all it has given me. Sadly years of the good old boys club, hiring of buddies, back scratching and poor decisions have made the place a toxic and dying company. It is only a matter if time before the company fails and the management walks away with money in their pocket at the expense of all the employees who tried to keep it going.  Upper management lacks creativity and compassion.  Too bad.

review_title: Arrived at Seagate via Sandforce->LSI->Avago acquisition, and got screwed in the process.
pros: Great work life balance at the moment, as management can not decide on projects to work on. We will soon have daily trips out of Silicon Valley to a Fremont facility that will allow us to experience startup like conditions in a big company.
cons:
This review is mainly specific to circumstances relating to arriving at Seagate via an acquisition (not a good thing). Seagate recently acquired the Flash Components Division of Avago Technologies, which previously acquired LSi, which previously acquired Sandforce. Many of the original Sandforce folks worked really hard to realize a technology and were still vesting a significant amount of the startup equity and mostly this vesting would have completed by late 2015. This equity had been maintained through the acquisition by LSI and Avago. Unfortunately Seagate chose not to recognize existing vesting schedules and came up with a retention scheme that basically screwed the longstanding creators of the technology. A gun was held to our heads in taking the deal to leave Avago and sign up with Seagate in which Avago threatened to withhold bonuses that would have been paid. Avago is basically a technology corporate raider that acquires companies and sells of pieces as it sees fit. 

This has now lead to a very negative work environment in which the main topic of discussion is how badly treated people were and what other opportunities are available outside of Seagate. A number of people have already left, and It seems like the team is on the verge of complete disintegration, and Seagate will have purchased technology assets that are worthless without the creators of the technology. This seems so stupid as $450m was paid for the acquisition and the amount that engineers were screwed out of was probably in the $10m range. 

I think it is already too late to save the Sandforce team, so posting this here for others that may end up in a similar situation. Get organized as a group early and protect yourself.

review_title: Good People... Bad Management... Ugly Industry
pros:
At my time at Seagate, I was always impressed by the people there. Most are very smart, ambitious, and are generally good people. Like all companies there is a very vocal minority that seems to ruin this, but if properly managed these people just become noise. 

The technology developed is very very advanced and is a great place to learn a lot of skills and subject areas quickly.
cons:
Morale during Industry Changes--
The HDD industry has significantly changed as SSD is now a certifiable competitor, although it is not going to forseeably kill the HDD industry it is going to take about half of the market. As such, Seagate and other HDD companies are significantly downsizing production, people, and places. For many industry veterans, this is a welcomed sight since they have sizable layoff packages waiting for the. The Mid/Early Career employees walk around afraid.

Lack of Strong Leadership--
During an industry downturn, Seagate needs strong,transparent leaders who can work with the new challenges and provide a path/plan for how Seagate will succeed in the new, reduced market. This simply is not the case at Seagate. All levels of management are deer in the headlights since they are afraid of their job being eliminated. 

Shareholders and Financial Engineering
The company's clear priority is the Shareholders over anything else. This is clearly evident through the debt-financed quarterly dividends. Right now, Seagate is at the top of the Technology S-Curve and needs to put more $ into innovating their way out of the rut they are in... especially with SSD. However, quarter after quarter, the priority is to deposit the remainder of all Free-Cash flow back to the share holders. Although there is nothing legally or ethically wrong with this, it does make employees wonder about their future there, and some suspect upper management's plan is to conduct a "Controlled Glide" as the HDD industry slowly all while those in power collect their checks.

Apart from me, I saw business unit employees (I was in IT)  putting in increasing hours, as conference calls with Asia increased and general demands of the business, especially after the accursed Maxtor acquisition.  (think 9pm conference calls -- oh, no prob, I'll take it at home).

I saw little oversight between middle-mgt and upper. There was no concern to root out bad managers, their word was always gold.  Saw at least two friends scapegoated out of the co.

Lots of re-orgs, swallow-ups, and moves, exacerbated by the Maxtor gobble-up in 05-06.   

STX left Scotts Valley (except a coupla buildings) for Cupertino earlier this year.  If you have the nerves of steel (and stomach for the high-pressure environment, at least in business units) to work for a big int'l corp with an offshore HQ model, Seagate is good on your resumé.   

Always remember to get another job while you still have one, don't wait till you're riffed!  If you leave after two years, just when you have learned the business, remember that corporate leadership likely doesn't care. Someone else will be hired to take on your duties, or if you are riffed, others have lots of free time to shoulder the load.
